title: Stackable Filing Tray cnc/laser
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
These stackable filing trays share quite some principles from the Compartment Storage Box. The assembly relies entirely on a glue and screw free press fit principle and – pretty obvious – the same material from closet back planes. Furthermore I added the same tappets with corresponding recess for stackability. A few kerfs help to bend the bottom a little.

I used a desktop cnc-machine by Stepcraft, but the design could be done with a laser as well.

Visit https://www.zenziwerken.de/en/ for more interesting designs. Consider a donation if you like the build.

Keep in mind that the stl was uploaded just for a three dimensional display here on Thingiverse.

Clear the holes

Use a rasp to clear the holes of the front part of the photo frame.

STEP 1 - The back part of photo frame

I used Openscad do design this part. This is made for a standard picture of 15x10

STEP 2 - The front part of photo frame

I search some images on internet and with inkscape i turn them into .dxf file and use it on openscad.

This is a simple support frame

STEP 1 - Materials

You will need:

  • Photo frame printed stl files
  • 1m EL Wire with inverter
  • Rasp
  • A photo
STEP 2 - Install the EL Wire

Pass the EL Wire through the hole and put it around the frame

STEP 3 - Install the support

Fit the support in the back part of the photo frame

STEP 4 - Add the photo

Choose a photo

STEP 5 - Fit the front part of the photo frame

Don't forget to use the rasp if needed!

STEP 6 - Turn on the EL Wire

Turn the EL Wire on and then turn off the lights

Now your photo disappears in the void...

All about EL Wire

title: Dasaki Compact Direct Drive Extruder for Prusa i3 (MK7 drive gear)

description.text:
Compact direct drive extruder for Nema 17 motors.

https://youtu.be/2DG1vYbFB0w

There are two versions, depending on the filament you use, for 1.75mm filament you have to add a 4mm OD/3mm ID PTFE tube piece.
There are also two options for each version, one with the motor pointing to the left and another one with the motor pointing to the right.
It allows a clear and nice view of the filament input hole. Includes a filament guide/pressure adjustment mechanism (use some glue to fix the knob to the M4 screw).
You can choose four different stiffness for the piece filament_guide: A,B,C and D, being A the softest (most flexible) and D the hardest (least flexible).
No supports needed, the supports are included in the 3D models.

You will need a hobbed Drive Gear (MK7 with approx. 10.56mm effective diameter, for MK8 drive gear see: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1844782) and the following hardware:

1x 623 bearing
1x M4x10mm-15mm screw, hexagonal head (knob)
1x M4 nut (knob holder)
3x M3x8mm screws (motor)
1x M3x10mm screw (bearing)
3x M3x25mm screws (assembly)
2x M3 nut (assembly)
1x M3 auto-locking (nylon) nut (assembly / filament guide)

Licensed under the TAPR Open Hardware License

If you are a curious maker / "tinker" / hacker, have a look at my blog:
http://www.therandomlab.com

Printer:

Prusa i3

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

25

Notes:

No supports needed, the supports are included in the 3D models.

author: Fazerboy

description.text:
Drill Press Vice
3" jaw width and opens 4.25"

This Drill Press Vice has replaceable jaws which could allow you to make custom soft jaws for special work holding applications and used them with the vice.
Some bolt lengths might need some trimming but the lengths given should be close.

To assemble the vice fully bolt the movable jaw on and the glue the 3/8 bolt into a 3/8 nut inside the movable jaw, this will allow the jaw to be retracted with normal operation. I got the idea from http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1547828
The second 3/8 nut is pressed into the vice body.
I didn't use any rafts but i did use support.
Parts are not orientated to print as they are in the files see what works for you the vise jaw printed best for me when rotated 180 degrees so that it was upside down.
On all parts I used 3 perimiters and I used 40% infill on all the parts except the vice body which I used 20%.
Hardware needed
(2X)3/8 nuts
(1X)3/8 X 8" bolt
(2X)1/4 X 2.5"
(2X)1/4 lock nuts
(2X)4mmX30mm
(2X)4mmX35mm
(4X)4mm nuts

Happy Printing

print_settings.Notes:: The large flat surfaces here benefit greatly from using glue stick on your build surface. I found otherwise the corners will lift. This won't effect the integrity of the build, but it will visually look bad. The print settings don't matter much, but you will need to have good accuracy with your printer width-wise or your lids won't work. (i.e. your extrusion multiplier may cause problems if you use one).

description.text:
Not based on the actual source, but my first attempt at using OpenSCAD. After printing the excellent boxes provided by makkuro, I found that they were for a bigger game box than I had. Mine only had 40mm of clearance after placing the gameboards inside.

I've tested everything except the divided box, because my printer isn't big enough to print the default settings (5 chip holders wide, holding 13 chips each). Instead you'll see the settings I use (4 chip holders wide, holding 22.5 chips each). These have been included for your convenience, or you can use the customizer and have fun. (That is also the chip holder shown in the splash folder).

This customizer creates 5 organizers. A goods organizer (four areas) and lid. Another goods holder with bumps (so it's easier to get the square cubes out). These two together will be 40mm high. A chip holder and lid (holds 13 chips in each, but has more total holders than the original by default). A chip holder sized box and lid with 5 areas (this is sized to sit on top the holder so it stacks to the 40mm height). (Though as noted, the attached STL are for my smaller printer).

Most of these parameters are customizable, please have fun and provide suggestions and feedback.

Will update with more photos of the other boxes soon.

Printer:

MP Select Mini

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

100%

Notes:

The large flat surfaces here benefit greatly from using glue stick on your build surface. I found otherwise the corners will lift. This won't effect the integrity of the build, but it will visually look bad. The print settings don't matter much, but you will need to have good accuracy with your printer width-wise or your lids won't work. (i.e. your extrusion multiplier may cause problems if you use one).

title: T4 Quadcopter Arm Remix for T-Motor Air Gear 350

description.text:
I can't say enough good things about Brendan's T4 Quadcopter design. It's an attractive, rugged 3-D printed quad frame that always attracts attention at the flying field.

I have seen a number of questions on Brendan's comments page about "what motor to use", so thought I would share what works for me. I have found that the T-Motor Air Gear 350 kit is almost a perfect match for this quad frame: http://www.rctigermotor.com/html/2014/Combo_pack_0930/279.html. This motor is sold as a "combo pack" complete with 920 kV motors, 9545 self-tightening props, and 20A ESCs, and retails for about $130. I use it with a 4S battery.

I have made a few small tweaks to Brendan's arm design, modified to accomodate the ESCs in the Air Gear 350 kit. This modification is similar to several other remixes for the arm.

comments.text: I was wondering if the T-Motor Air Gear 350 kit would be good for this drone.  Glad to hear it works for you.  I'm still trying to decide how I should outfit this guy, being new to drones and all.
comments.author: dgk816

comments.text: Yes, it is an excellent combination for this drone!  I use it with a 4S 5000 mAh battery, and it gets plenty of power and speed with over 15 minutes of flight time.  I used the website eCalc.ch to size the motors/batteries before committing to the Air Gear 350, and have been very pleased.
comments.author: dgk816

comments.text: That's good to hear, especially since I ordered the kit today :)

Here is a simple parametric lid generator that I've found useful for containers as well as telescope lens caps.

comments.text: Possibly adding a slightly (customizable) narrower rim at the base could constitute an improvement to your lid: That way most of the lid can slide easily over whatever it's covering, and only the narrower rim at the base takes hold. That's especially useful for somewhat deeper lids, which may otherwise be hard to remove. With that mod they appear to "click" on and off. Tried and tested with covers for zoom flashlights, protecting the plastic lenses.
comments.author: Bushmills

comments.text:
thanks Bushmills, that was exactly the case i was hoping to handle when i added the bottom lip to this design.
(the bottom lip here is disabled by default, but can be sized and re-enabled in openscad or in the customizer app).
comments.author: Bushmills

comments.text:
with the bottom rim, I prefer straight over conical, but that depends fo course on the shape of the item the lid is pulled over. I specify lip size by difference from inner diameter size, therefore saying how thick I want it to be. I tend to hardcode it, rather than keeping it in a variable - which is also why my simplistic cap design hasn't been published. For the mentioned flashlight, the rim radius is 0.2 mm shorter than lid inner diameter. I've made it as "unpublished" available under http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1816487 - as is, it fits perfectly the flashlight from http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1801936
You may have noticed that the file has been more adequately parameterized now, and what I wrote above partially doesn't apply any longer. I keep it "unpublished" though, there is no need to compete with your design.

print_settings.Notes:: Almost any settings should work.  I printed it in PLA.  It's a pretty small part, so maybe print a few at a time, or use some extra cooling while it's finishing off the top parts, which are very small.

description.text:
This is a little mounting plate to go on the top of a race quadcopter (or any other kind), and which has little holes for the FRSKY receiver antennas (i.e. D4R-II or X4R receivers). These holes are sized to accommodate a hopefully-standard-sized coffee stirrer straw (I think I got mine at Starbucks) with the antenna wire routed inside for protection. Designed to be mounted on the top of a quadcopter with a bit overlapping the edge so the antenna wires can be inserted from underneath. I held it down with servo tape and a zip tie.

The antenna slots are angled at 25 deg and 55 deg rearward, with one angled inside by 10 deg and one angled outward at 10 deg. These angles are a best-guess to ensure at least one is nearly vertical when in forward flight. Probably best to put a tiny dab of superglue when inserting the coffee-stirrer into the holder, to help keep it in place.

Two models available... one meant to overhang the right side of a quad, and one to overhang the left. Antennas should tilt backward when you're all done... unless you fly mostly in reverse, of course.

Notes:

Almost any settings should work. I printed it in PLA. It's a pretty small part, so maybe print a few at a time, or use some extra cooling while it's finishing off the top parts, which are very small.

print_settings.Infill:: 10% for the rings, 50% for the flat parts

However, the props included in this project do not have the text inscribed on them as they do in the Suicide Squad (2016) feature film. This build consists of six files, with the main base of each magnum split in half to fit certain printer beds. If you do print this, I highly encourage you to remix this build. And if you do have any complications, questions, or concerns with the build, please, notify me so I can make corrections to the files or I can get back to you with the information you require. author: AlainDucros

description.text:
Quick Update
I chunked it up so it could be printed on my smaller printer (Printrbot Play), I'll post pics of the build once it's complete.

I wanted a scope for an A280 for another prop gun I have so I cut it off of the full Battlefront A280 by Osmethae. I also found another version online buried in a forum from a few years back (looking for the source for proper credit) which had an open rear for inserting a real scope. I liked the forward tip on this one so I cut it off and replaced Osmethae's tip with this other one. Thus there are three scopes here, 1, Osmethae's original, 2, the open back forum scope, and finally, my Scopenstein combination. Mine ended up getting sent through a "smoother" feature of one of the softwares I used along the way so it is a little softer on some edges and angles, but overall I think it improved things, particularly the rear scope's adjustment knobs, which are now quite round. Shouldn't be hard to recreate it with the original files provided if you dont like it softer though.

Happy hunting!

description.text: Robotwars Antweight robot inspired by Carbide

Printer:

E3D Bigbox

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2 - 0.25

Infill:

25% - 100%

Notes:

The tyres and belt should be printed in Ninjaflex or similar soft TPU/TPE. The belt is thin enough that infill doesnt matter. The tyres at 25% infill should be fine.

The blade should be printed in something that wont shatter, e.g. nylon at 100% infill.

The rest of the parts can be printed in pretty much whatever you want.

Other bits

This is a rough list at the moment, I'll update it soon

Motor
1 x Turnigy 1811 2200kv Brushless motor

Servos
2 x HXT900 modified for continuous rotation and using tiny jst connectors for the radio

Radio
1 x FRSky V5DM

Battery
1 x 2s 180mah Turnigy Nanotech

Switch
1 x mini SPDT
https://www.amazon.co.uk/gp/product/B00KBPSNE4/ref=oh_aui_detailpage_o01_s00?ie=UTF8&psc=1

ESC
1 x Hobbyking xc-10a

Bearings
3 x 8mm x 4mm x 3mm bearings for the blade
1 x 5mm x 2.5mm x 2mm bearing for the motor spindle

Fasteners
1 x m3 35mm cap head bolt
1 x dome m3 nut
Some m2 and m3 washers
Some 2mm screws 6-8mm

description.text:
I loved the feel of the grips by zeroordie881, however there were some annoyances; There were sharp edges my fingers would dig into when wrapping around the grips, the Gameboy would fall out of the case when opening up the lid or playing in bed, and while in the case you couldn't access the cartridges to change games. Here's what I changed:

First off the pins at the top that click into the wrist strap holes didn't print with my 0.4mm nozzle. Seeing that they were only half height I extended them to ensure they would print.

I also added tabs at the lower corners near the grip. This ensures it doesn't pop out of the case when opening the lid, and in combination of the pins at the top, help hold the 3DS securely in the case.

I contoured the back to add comfort and strength. This thing feels great.

Print just like zeroordie881's design standing up on the bottom of the grips. major supports needed with minor cleanup

If you have the original 3DS XL you can find the grip I created for that here:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1833730

comments.text: I printed mine in white PLA and may have a sizing issue that I'm not sure how to handle. The clips on the top have about 1/8 of an inch clearance and do not hold the N 3DS XL. comments.text: Thanks! The horizontal dimensions are perfect, just this little bit extra made it really painful. I'm still getting my machine to a point of print and forget, running into issues with initial bed adhesion and retraction. This print had a ton of strings all over the place for the supports. I had to print is standing up at a 45 degree angle across the build plate and added supports using the latest version of Cura. I'm still pretty new to 3d printing and haven't done much model editing on my own. I was debating giving a plastidip coating to this but didn't know how much the plastidip would improve this gap. Do you know the expected thickness of a Plastidip coat? I sliced it on Cura with the default fine settings with the changes of slower printer movements and a Raft for bed adhesion. It ended up being about a 24 hour print with besides the gap being AMAZING. Thanks for the reply.

Supports:

Yes

The Andrew Fork is an assistive device for the two-handed task of cutting food with a knife and fork. Young Andrew Forest was unable to comfortably grasp a fork with his right hand, so he used modeling clay to shape a special handle for his fork. His mom baked the assembly in the oven to make it rigid enough for Andrew to use. This seemed like such a good idea that we wondered if Andrew’s invention would be useful for other people with hand differences. So we used Tinkercad to develop the fork handle for 3D Printing.

The design fits a fork available from the Dollar Tree store in a 2-pack for $1. Do not use PLA filament (so that the assembly can be washed in a dishwasher). The STL file allows for the shrinkage in ABS and Nylon. For flexible material like Cheetah or rigid filament that does not shrink, try a version that is scaled to .9 on the x-axis in your slicer. A ziptie can be used to secure the fork in the handle.

If you don’t have a 3D printer, try getting a quote from 3D Hubs or Shapeways or do a google search on 3D printing services with your zipcode.

Feel free to hack or remix the design to make it fit your fork better. You can start with the Tinkercad File. Or do what Andrew and other e-NABLE volunteers are doing and develop some other assistive devices for other tasks. We would love to hear if Andrew’s invention works for other people too.

Go to the Enable Community Foundation website or to the Enabling The Future website to join our free and open source community.

Challenge:
What we really need is a design with a simple geometry that will securely capture a wide range of fork sizes and shapes. Consider remixing the Tinkercad design for the 267 Fork Handle and see what you can come up with.

description.text:
This was a project that a friend of mine requested I make. All of the data comes from NOAA/National Centers for Environmental Information and comes from http://www.ngdc.noaa.gov/mgg/greatlakes/michigan.html. This model is considered in the public domain as the information is freely available online and you need to attribute that the data came from NOAA.

The point cloud that I started from had around 22 million data points and was a bit of a challenge to work with on my computer. The model is incredibly detailed as you can make out the islands in the northern part of the lake and if you print in multi-color the details standout even more. Just use the M600 GCdr printer supports it to get the the multicolor prints if you don't have a multi-color printer.

If you have a problem with this file, let me know so I can check it out and possibly fix it.

Printer:

Original Prusa i3

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.2mm

Infill:

20

Notes:

Had problems with this print on Simplify 3d but Cura sliced it properly and without issues. If you manage to get this to print cleanly on Simplify 3D on a Prusa i3. Let me know about your settings.

Multi-colors were achieved by injecting a filament change command manually into the GCode files.

Take it slow in the top layers as I had issues with the layers peeling away if I was going too fast.

description.text:
Recently I read an awesome article about the Egyptian numbers and Math wrote by Raúl Ibáñez:

http://culturacientifica.com/2016/09/21/multiplicar-no-dificil-los-egipcios-los-campesinos-rusos/

(In spanish)

If you don't know spanish you can also read:

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ancient_Egyptian_mathematics

And I also recommend this awesome video:

https://teded.herokuapp.com/lessons/a-brief-history-of-numerical-systems-alessandra-king

Reading the article I found out that the Egyptian maths were so interesting, I made some sums and multiplications and I decided to make a phisical versión of the egyptian numbers with an special box to make the sums (multiplications are more complex, and you'll need a paper)

In my opinion is a funny kit to learn some history in a history or math classroom.

Hope you like it!

Printer:

Prusa i3 Hephestos

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Infill:

At least 15%

Notes:

To make sums without problems you must print at least 20 units of every number. I printed 25 units in different colors for each number.

In the sum box I put some squares on the left to write the numbers. The only thing that you have to do is cut and glue some paper white cardboard in the squares.

I also painted in white the math symbols.

description.text:
https://youtu.be/xlwXr_vfx_I

This gun needs no supports, as it already comes with it's on that just snap off easy once finished. This gun comes with a comfortable grip handle to hold with your left hand, it also comes with a rubber band dispenser that you wrap a rubber band around the tiny pole on the inside of the front piece under the aiming part and then wrap more rubber bands around that rubber band around the pole, and unwrap them as you like. title: DRO mount for Emco Unimat 3/4, MJ-189 mini lathe
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Simple mount for a DRO (modified caliper) to the base of a EMCO Unimat 3 or 4 or a similar type mini lathe clone, e.g. MJ-189.
Required:

  • printed parts
    mounts: DRO_1 & DRO_2,
    caps: DRO_1b & DRO_2b
    carriage driver arm DRO_3
  • 4x M3x10mm screws
  • 1x left-handed 300mm caliper (for EMCO Unimat 3: https://www.amazon.de/gp/product/B00CDROLCG/ref=oh_aui_detailpage_o06_s00?ie=UTF8&psc=1)

Why a left-handed caliper?
Because then you can mount it on the right side of the carriage and count positive values when moving the carriage to the head stock.

Print all parts, cut down the caliper (arms, lenght)
If required use a file to rework the printed parts as well as the caliper to make sure that the caliper is well seated and the caps have a tight fit.
Use the clamping screw of the caliper to mount it to the carriage driver arm.

comments.text: Nice idea. I made something similar many years ago, pre 3D printers, and found that angling the readout up to 45 degrees made reading the dial easier. As it is, you might find having to stoop/bend down to see the readout gets annoyoying, as did I.

title: Echo DOT Sound Enhancer - Wall Mount/Holder

description.text:
This is a multi use Mount/Stand for the Amazon Dot 2. It has a curved lower section to redirect the sound out from under the unit to enhance the sound. I tested this with my unit and it seems to work well. Thought he sounds does not seem to have a major change when sitting on a hard surface, it does prevent the muffling of the sound when the unit is sitting on something soft, such as a fabric table covering. The Alexa Dot fits securely into the top allowing you to mount this in a multitude of way. I left space on the bottom to allow for the use of small rubber feet, and holes to allow mounting using screws. You can place this on you desk or mount it on your wall. It's all up to you. One of my units is mounted on the wall near my Spa (more than 5' away) to allow me to have control over my lighting and music without having to worry about mixing water and electric.

It is my understanding that Dot 1.0 has the same lateral dimensions as 2.0. If so, you should be able to use this with that model as well. Doing so would result in the side spikes not entirely reaching all the way to the top of the unit, but I see no reason why it would not work.

Printer Brand:

MakerBot

Printer:

MakerBot Replicator 2

Rafts:

No

No

Resolution:

100

Infill:

15%

Notes:

I printed the pictured one using 100/layer, but it would look fine at 200/layer. I wanted a really nice finish and time was not an issue for the print.

This was deigned using TinkerCad. It is similar to others out there, but was designed from the ground up to allow for a multitude of small changes including screw holes, elliptical sound reflector, feet placements, art-deco design.It is matched to the new Echo DOT 2.0 dimensions.

comments.text: I'm sorry, but i cant. The full size Alexa has a different speaker configuration. the speakers are downward facing in it, but they are designed to radiate outwards from the bottom half of the units sides. The DOT actually directs is one and only speaker downward. If the DOT is sitting on a soft surface, the sound gets absorbed and does not radio. The Full Alexa on the other hand, does not have that issue. It did design a full size Alexa cover, but it does not enhance the sound. it only makes it look a little classier (in my opinion :) )

comments.text: Yeah it looks like, from your profile, you're using an i3 variant. They aren't the most sturdy printers out there, I would recommend dropping down to ~40mm/sec speed and drastically lowering your acceleration values (or Jerk settings depending on your slicer of choice). The acceleration and jerk settings will determine the velocity curve of each move segment. a more gradual curve will mean less lateral forces acting on your frame to slow down and change the direction of the nozzle.
comments.author: TheExpertNoob

comments.text: Sounds like you need to either enforce your printers frame, or slow down your print speed/acceleration. I printed mine around 30-40mm/sec, but this is because I printed it in PETG and it's a limitation of the plastic. I also have relatively low acceleration values, I could go much higher as I have a delta printer, but I err on the side of caution. I'd rather have good looking successful prints than potentially volatile fast ones.
comments.author: TheExpertNoob

comments.author: Fuganater

comments.text: I print them pin side down, or thumb cap side up. With support material that is more dense on the final support layer. And at .2mm. I use simplify3d, their supports are pretty good, you may have to play around with density and gaps. My supports were difficult to remove, razor blade and needle nose pliers were absolutely necessary

title: Folger Tech FT-5 TFT32 Screen mount (Rev 3)

description.text:
This is a mount for the TFT32 color touch screen. It includes the main housing and a back cover. The back cover was just revised with this upload so it may not fit. I haven't printed it out yet. Maybe someone will beat me to it.

Give em a shot!

Round two!

I have modified this whole assembly to acquire a back door that snaps into place. I am looking for people to get some prints of this stuff done to see if it works, as I am backed up with prints to test this yet. Would love any feedback you can provide. To my models and knowledge it should fit but I have been wrong before.

You will need support for both parts, I recommend printing at 100 micron and whatever speed your machine is good with 100 micron. Infill could do at 30% or so.

Round 3

I had a request from a fellow user that they have experienced a lack of usb clearance as well as losing the sd card back behind the mount resulting in disassembly of the mount.

As before my printer is still down (I have about 2 pieces of hair left on my head) so please provide feedback to this model.

Case for a raspberry pi zero, and an inland (microcenter brand) usb hub. Youll need:
raspberry pi zero
inland 4 port usb hub
5mm led and panel mount holder
type n panel mount barrel jack connector
wire
2.2k ohm resistor
panel mount rocker switch that fits.
hot glue
self tapping screws #4-20 8x
epoxy

Throw all ingredients into box, and shake until desired arrangement is entropically generated.

print_settings.Notes:: All 4 pieces are printed flat on plate, you need support, but theres really small amount of support, so you will not have problem removing it. I used PLA but its surely printable with ABS, all parts can fit one by one on 200x200mm plate, but you need to put barrels diagonaly to fit on plate. You can glue it down with acetone or ordinary glue for plastic, i personally used ordinary glue and held it down with rubber bands, and later sanded it.

description.text: Mounts to attach Moujen waterproof limit switches to a Grizzly G0704 for a cnc conversion

An IKEA Hack and a Remix.

Start with IKEA Härliga Glass Dome, and print a number of the things that you like, in this case squirrel pawns, which I use to test filament. I built up a lighted base, printer in a woodfil, lens printed with natural PLA, and the created the stands, all stl and123D Design files here to reuse. Lights are LED types that you can get on eBay or amazon, run on 12V. Printed on Prusa Original I3 MK2.

Printer:

Prusa Orignal i3 MK2

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

No

Resolution:

200m

Infill:

20%

Notes:

3 Perimeters and 20% infill on the base and stand
160 Perimeters and 0% infill on the lens, which makes it a continuous spiral two layers deep.

Build the base

Light sanding, and insert the LEDs,most will do a better job on this than me.

description.text: Manual juicer that does not require electric power. The juicer can be used during power outages, trips, or just in general over electric powered juicers. PopPlanter

Here is my simple self watering / hydroponic pot which uses the bottom from a 2L drinks bottle as I have been having problems getting my prints to come out truly watertight.

Note: The files here are sized with no clearance so that you can scale them to fit your required bottle size.

  • Measure your plastic bottle.
  • The STLs are sized for 100mm diameter bottles to make scaling easier.
    • Reservoir - Set the X and Y axis scale factor to match the outer diameter of your bottle. For example - for a 98mm diameter bottle you would set the scale to 98%
    • Pot - Set the X and Y axis scale factor to match the inner diameter of your bottle and allow a bit for clearance.

The pot is designed to use capillary matting as a wick and I have used this to great success to grow lettuce and other leaf crops.

title: Hictop Extruder Stepper Motor Mount for 3DP acrylic printers

description.text:
During the effort to mount dual j-head bowden-style extruders on my Hictop Prusa i3 Acrylic-body printer, I needed a place to mount the extruder stepper remotely from the hotend. This places it behind the display mount, latching it to the top two corner braces. You will need longer M3 screws in those 2 spots to attach this.

V3 is an add-on part that retains your existing corner brace.

V4 replaces the brace, making it one piece. This also required making separate R and L models, and that's reflected in the two files.

comments.text: Thanks for this, just printed the V4 excellent for single or Dual Extruder setups! Dual here I come. Was it a lot of work to fine tune the bowden setup?

description.text: Mounts 2 x 40mm fans, one for the hotend and one for the printed part aswell as three 5mm LEDs around a E3D V5 or V6 hotend on a Mendelmax 2 X carriage.

Notes:

I used support for the straight parts of the fan ducts, but it should be possible to print without if you want to.

Print with ABS, PA, PET, PEI or similar

It is mounted using 5 M5x10 bolts and nuts. You'll have to extend the 4.2 mm holes of the x carriage with a drill.

I used 3 super bright white 5mm leds in series with a 120 Ohm resistor on 12V in parallel to the hotend fan connected to 12V. There are feedthroughs to wire the LEDs.

The frontal fan cools the printed part and is controlled by the microcontroller.

title: Prusa i3 Bowden hot end mount

description.text:
This is a hot end mount for the Prusa i3 x-carriage. It is suitable for Bowden hot ends from Tech3d.org.   
It can be used with the hobbed bolt Bowden drive. Although a mount needs to be created for the i3:  www.thingiverse.com/thing:172702   
To attach the double mount I used two M3 x 16s socket cap screws and one countersunk M3 x 15. It seems to fit flush without the bottom countersunk screw.   
The single mount isn't perfect; I need to integrate the bottom hole. At the moment it can be attached with two M3 x 16s.  
I haven't built a Prusa i3 yet, so if you build one please give me some feedback.

description.text: My web-blogger wife has been doing more and more Facebook Live videos as part of her social media strategy. She asked me to find a way to connect her iPhone to our tripod allowing her to make the videos without holding the phone. One thing to note, this was very difficult to pry from the print bed once it was finished. I used the tripod baseplate as noted and designed this in OpenSCAD. I would post the source, but I did it really quick and it's a magic number mess that I'm too embarrassed to share.

remixed_from.author: ZeAllan
remixed_from.title: Arduino Uno Protective BasePlate with flaps

title: Arduino Uno Protective BasePlate with flaps and mounting holes

description.text:
I printed ZeAllan's Arduino base plate -- http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1300706 based on the original work of jakob_dk2300 -- http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1173172 and it worked well. I liked the idea of not needing screws to hold the Arduino in, and that there were no large holes in the base for something metal to get through and short the board.

However, ZeAllan's version was still a bit tight on the Elegoo Arduino Uno R3 that I had purchased. Trying to insert or remove the card into the base gave me visions of torn skin on the sharp pins on the back of the board. And there were no mounting holes. So I enlarged the part every so slightly and increased it's height. I also reformed the pegs that go through the rear holes of the circuit board to be a bit taller and more tapered. And I added mounting points.

A nice working base for the Arduino Uno and a way to mount it where it's needed for testing. Thanks to all involved!

title: Cover for the ROK coffee grinder

description.text:
This is a cover for the ROK coffee grinder.

There's an issue with this (actually pretty good) grinder coming from beans or splinters escaping the funnel and hitting peoples eyes and making a mess - this is why it needs a cover.

There's a slider to increase the cover area. There would be another easy way to even increase the cover area further... maybe someday I'll redesign it for that (edit: done).

The vertical structure on the nipple is just support. Cut it away when the print is done.

28.08.2017: I updated the design (deckel45*.stl) because the old one was shit, especially the nipple. I strongly recommend printing the new one.

28.08.2017: I just realized that the new handle looks like a dick. And after the mechanism wears in there's no handle needed anymore anyway... so let's consider the handle as optional.

29.10.2017: Got the dick-issue fixed (now it looks like a beak) and made the tolerances a bit more loose. I also updated the pictures.

title: Planetary gear bearing filament spool holder for 30x30 and 20x20 extrusion

description.text:
Vid: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=qn0oaJO6jUU

Spool holder and bearing system I designed for use on the Wombot Exilis XL, will work on any printer using 30x30 or 20x20 extrusion in the frame (there are files for the bearing tower in each size).

Designed for easy assembly. Simply put the axle into one of the inserts and slide the universal insert into the spool, and slide the other insert in from the other side over the axle... the axle keeps them nice and centered and eliminates sag in the spool. Then you put the bearings over the hexes on the inserts, and drop the whole assembly into the cups on the towers.

The bearing towers don't need to be printed with support, as I have designed a support into it for the overhanging lip when printing it on it's side... these diagonal zig zag supports need to be removed with a screwdriver following printing... it's very easy.

The spool locking insert are designed to fit most generic spools, and the axle is used to keep the inserts aligned and keep everything rotating smoothly.

Message me if you require different sizes and I will be happy to whip up different spec inserts and axles to suit your spools.

The planetary gear bearing is not my design, and was customised using Emmett's Gear Bearing here on thingiverse. I have simply taken it and tidied the outside geometry slightly. It works flawlessly, providing exceptionally smooth rotation of the spool and gentle continuous filament supply with no strain on the extruder. A bit of silicone lubricant spray makes it turn even smoother.

description.text:
Spool holder for many sizes of spools. Uses the same style spindle/arm design of my mini spool holder.
Uses friction and the locking spindle to hold onto the mini. I've included 2 version. One with Connectors one without. The connector was inspired from another spool holder, but it doesn't really hold well itself. If you decide you need it with the connector it does reduce the overall spool holding ability by a few mm. I would drill and pin the connector if you use the connector version.
I've included the spacers I use for the different spools I have as well.

Printer:

Monoprice Select Mini

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.20

Infill:

50%

Notes:

The only supports needed are for the small retainers that hang in the air. These set into the frame to keep the back from sliding out of the frame while the front spindle holds the front locking it on the mini.

comments.text: These work great! I used BuildTak which does not completely cover my bed so the ends were drooping. Since I was printing in PLA I just put some blue tape (well, mine is green) on the edges. Two layers were as thick as the BuildTak. Roughed up the tape with sandpaper and there it is. Be sure to turn on support although I did one without and the little lip came out OK but not great.

comments.author: jasonjones

comments.text: Simplify3d, the only support is on the little tag end, no brim or raft, it has plenty of surface to adhere to the bed. Rotate it to fit the bed. Make sure you have your bedsize set properly 120mm x 120mm and not shorter. Your mini will actually do about 124x124 easily, and with some testing you might get it out to 126mm. Keep rotating it on the Z axis (flat spin) till it fits on the bed. You can only fit 1 at a time btw, don't try and fit both or all the pieces.

comments.text:
I am a newbie in 3D printing and I read so often about "oilers" but haven't found any more information about it. Since you are showing here another oiler, can you please give me some more information about oiling the filaments? What kind of oil do you use and what are the benefits of oiling the filaments besides cleaning from dust? Any disadvantages? A link to additional information would also be nice.
Thanks in advance and kind regards
comments.author: TuxMan

comments.text: I am a newbie as well.  I am still learning on how to improve my 3D print from exploring different setup on my MK2.  Anyway, the benefit of using an oiler is to clean any debris or dust from the filament before extruding.  I cannot think of any side effect or disadvantage from using it.  You can use a drop of olive oil and make sure you do not over do it.  Over saturate is bad and the ideal amount of oil is to lightly coat the filament and clean off any dust from the filament.  There are tons of videos from YouTube that talk about this.  Go check them out and happy printing.
comments.author: TuxMan

it seems like it is printing sloppy, creating an 'absolute' chaotic output. You will notice the stl file
represents a clear cylindric design but when changing
the gcode to its limits, the thing-o-matic prints a non-clear cylindric design.

When you have a thing-o-matic with 1.75 filament,
you can apply following settings in replicator G version 0027 : On button 'generate gcode' make following settings :

  • no raft

  • use Print-O-Matic and set :
    infill : 20
    layer height : 1
    numer of shells : 2
    feedrate : 30

comments.text: OK, so is the 'chaos' all caused by making the layer height 1mm, when the plastic is only 0.4mm thick (at the nozzle)? I'm guessing that would leave a gap where the plastic could noodle around a bit, particularly after going up a few layers, so it's basically dropping a line of plastic down to do as it will.
comments.author: laird

comments.text: This is quite thought provoking. The aesthetic effect produced by leaving the plastic "wiggly noodles" is quite nice, and it makes me want to see what happens when printing a castle - would it look like the dripping sand castles that we made as kids?

title: 3D printed Ghost Pendant with LED Eyes

description.text: At the World Maker Faire at New York on Oct 1-2, 2016, we were giving out these ghost necklace pendants with LED eyes. It became quite popular among the kids at the Faire. We had multiple colors for them to choose from for both the printed ghosts and the LEDs. Even the adults wanted to make one for themselves. Indeed, we unfortunately ran out of ghosts before everyone had a chance to get one. Therefore, we decided to make the files for this item open-source so that everyone could have a chance to make one at home. Here I have provided both the STLs and print profiles I used to make the ghost. The ghost part can be printed with either the glow-in-dark or translucent PLA. The electrical circuit is printed with Electrifi Conductive Filament that we developed at Multi3D (https://www.multi3dllc.com/product/electrifi-filament-sample/). The Electrifi can be attached to the back of the ghost using double-sided tape. After assembling the circuit, battery holder, and LEDs, you can simply smush the Electrifi into the LED contacts using a soldering iron to complete the circuit. Now just let it cool, and then insert the coin cell battery. This is a 20-min project. Have fun!

Printer:

Prusa i3

Rafts:

No

No

Resolution:

0.4 mm nozzle, 0.2 mm layer thickness

Infill:

Ghost: 20%; Circuit: 100%

Notes:

The circuit is printed on a sheet of polypropylene. Polypropylene is used because the Electrifi can be easily detached from the polypropylene sheet afterwards.

Preparing Bearings

comments.text:
Could be operator error - but this printed with holes just slightly too big for my standard 608RS 22mm bearings.
Took an hour and a half on a Monoprice Select Mini - but time was wasted since the bearings won't stay.
I had to superglue them in.
comments.author: Feastish

comments.text: I have a few different files for different types of filament at this point, each of them having hole sizes that vary by a fraction of a millimeter. One for PLA, one for wood fill, and one for TPU. The printer and slicer settings probably also have something to do with the fit of the bearings. The tolerances are so fine for a press fit that it may just take a little trial and error for each printer/filament/settings to be dialed in correctly. The file seen here is the one that I use to print PLA spinners. The dimension in the CAD for the hole size is 22.2mm. If the holes are too small or large you can probably just scale it a percent or two.

print_settings.Notes:: Print with 0.2mm layers to make sure the internal gaps print properly.

description.text:
This is a smaller, 4-leaf redesign of emmett's totally amazing Preassembled Iris Box (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1811143). After studying emmett's design carefully and with some advice from emmett himself, I managed to design a 60mm diameter version that prints faster. I also increased the internal clearances somewhat to make it less challenging to print. Like emmett's, it prints pre-assembled and without supports. Thanks, emmett!

Update: In my original version, the outer sphere was a little wobbly when closed and could cause jams. I've updated it to help prevent this problem. I've also included the Solidworks (2011) model for anyone to hack on.

Printer Brand:

MakerGear

Printer:

M2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

20%

Notes:

Print with 0.2mm layers to make sure the internal gaps print properly.

The bottoms of the 4 leafs print directly on the table and can be seen in the 4 slots in the bottom. To keep the leafs from breaking free during printing, I added 4 thin tabs attaching each leaf bottom to the outer ring. Use a razor blade or hobby knife to cut away these tabs.

The outer sphere is actually a dial that rotates. To free it, stick a small screw driver in the gap above the base ring and gently pry it free, working around the whole perimeter. Depending on how good your printer is with small gaps, you may need to insert a thin blade into the gaps at the top to free the leafs.

comments.text: After calibrating my new printer to within 0.1mm of calibration prints I figured it was time to try something harder. I always like Iris boxes so I figured I would give this a go. I was wrong. The inside fused together in several spots because of stringing. And, it magically printed with the pins on the wrong side internally some how. However, I will not be discouraged. I am calibrating for stringing and will give it another try. I will not surrender!

comments.text: This design has the inner and outer shells both fused to the base. You can see this in the preview of the sliced object. Your cross section image shows the outer shell magically floating above the base, but in reality it is fused. The screwdriver separation trick does not work for me without destroying the lower grip. If you instead modeled many tiny weak support struts for the outer shell it might break free by twisting. As it is, this design (and the one it's remixed from) do not work with by printer due to how firmly the outer shell is fused to the base.
comments.author: Jinja

comments.text: The gaps between the inner/outer shells and the leaves are ample. I can easily slide my thin spatula all the way in with no resistance. Changing the layer thickness (Z thickness) does not change the XY thickness and tolerances, so does not affect the gaps between the leaves in anyway as the slicing tool considers the nozzle thickness when deciding how close to the wall edge it should plot. My problem is how solid the outer shell is fused to the base. When looking at the slice output, the outer wall is attached to the base by a solid double extrusion. No wonder it wont budge. I suspect that if the outer wall was instead attached to the base by a number of tiny mounts, it would break free with a firm twist. I love this ingenious design by the way, except for this one issue.
comments.author: LoboCNC

comments.text: If you look at the cross section of the model (7th image), you will see that there is a 0.2mm gap between the base and the outer sphere.  If you slice with a 0.2mm layer thickness, you should find that in the preview of your sliced output, there will be exactly one layer where the outer sphere is not attached to the base ring.  In reality, the outer sphere will end up weakly fusing to the base ring, but can easily be broken free by prying inward with a screwdriver.  (Note that I am talking about the vertical gap between the outer sphere and the base ring, not the horizontal gaps.)

comments.text: Almost everything in this model is a thin wall, so if you specify 3 perimeters with a 0.4mm line width, 3 top & bottom layers, everything should print OK.  You should look at the print preview and make sure all of the thin sections are filled in.  If not, adjust the line width a little one way or the other.  (The newest version of S3D will automatically adjust the line width to get full infill on thin walls.)

comments.text: If you haven't watched this video (https://youtu.be/L5bD2DMX8BE) yet, it shows how to get the pieces freed up. However, if you end up with any blobs between the leafs and outer or inner shells, you'll still have lots of problems. In Simplify3D you may want to turn on the "coast" option as this tends to reduce stringing and blobbing. You may also need to increase your retraction. If you only have minor blobs or stringing inside, you can sometimes use a feeler gauge or thin shim to snake between the surfaces and free them up.

comments.text:
imho that design has a big issue... the external sphere, which needs to be "free to turn", is firmly stuck to the bottom layers, with no brittle parts. If you print hard solid, you will never be able to unstuck it, and this will result either to a "non working thing" or a "broken thing".
This design needs to have holes and bridges to make the external sphere "easy to unstuck"...
the other parts are wonderfull
comments.author: Lewil

comments.text: If you slice with exactly 0.2mm layers as indicated, there should be a skipped layer between the external sphere and the base.  Essentially, bottom layers act as a raft for the outer sphere, which you can then break free using a screw driver as shown in the photos.  Also, if you read through the other comments, you'll find additional tips on getting the parts freed up.
comments.author: Lewil

comments.text:
there is:
on slice 5 the externals and internal rings start up to build
http://hpics.li/f627e90
then on slice 6, (so skipping 1 slice of 0.2 as slice 5) the moving ring starts
http://hpics.li/d015830
comments.author: LoboCNC

comments.text: Leaving a single layer gap is how rafts are normally done.  You do get some adhesion between the 4th and 6th layers, but is should be weak enough that it can be broken free pretty easily.  (There's not that much surface area on the bottom of the outer sphere.)  If it is really firmly stuck, you may be over extruding or printing at too hot a temperature or printing too slowly.

comments.text: first thing you can start with is making sure the filament diameter is correct in the slicer, then esteps, then the extrusion multiplier. Most problems with print-in-place objects start with the incorrect extrusion multiplier; if the parts are stuck together your ex multiplier might be to high. Your right though it can be daunting to figure out the exact variables to why your prints aren't coming out like they should but you can rule out a lot of them buy just observing your printer print. The parts are fusing together; you're extruding too much filament; what settings control the amount of filament being extruded?Filament diameter, esteps,  and extrusion multiplier(there are some more but these are the main ones). That doesnt work what else can it be? Maybe there's big blobs at the end of my loop causing layers to fuse so i need to increase the retraction. My point being is depending on the situation you can rule out 85% those variables leaving you with 15% of guess work.

comments.text: Correct - the outer sphere turns clockwise to close.  If after you've cut the tabs on the bottom the whole unit seems rock solid, that means that the outer sphere has not been broken free from the base ring.  This is where you stick a flat-blade screwdriver into the gap between them and pry gently upwards.  If there is some movement of the outer sphere, but it still won't close, then the leafs are stuck.  You may be able to shove a thin shim into the gaps to try and free them.  Studying the semi-transparent CAD image will help you see what is going on.

comments.text:
A great and absolutely stunning model as this can not be built using "conventional" manufacturing techniques. Thank you!
Sliced with Skeinforce (50) it took about 5h to print and worked perfectly.
Unfortunately I was unable to produce another good print of the model using other slicers. I was trying MakerBot Dekstop v.3.10, Slic3r v1.2.9 and CarftWare v1.14beta with the same settings as far as possible. All G-Codes generated by the other slicers would either fuse the fins together with the inner shell at the edges or at the hinges. The problem seems to be different combinations of oozing, amount of extrusion for infills, traversing points and build-order of the individual layers by the different algorithms.

comments.text: Running a knife in the groove won't free the sphere because the blade is at the wrong angle. description.text: This is designed as a magnet face so you will need to find a magnet and super glue if you want to use it for a magnet.
Customized version of http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:74322 Created with Customizer! http://www.thingiverse.com/apps/customizer/run?thing_id=74322

Using the following options: image_file = lithopane20131111-1047-h1x28p-0.dat
hole_diameter = 10

description.text:
I originally made this a year ago for the iPhone 5 Otterbox defender, which I never shared as there were several versions. One mount for the door for my printer, one as a holder for my passenger side headrest to keep my daughter entertained in the car, and another as a mount on the wall for charging.
This current design has been revised for all three uses. The three holes in the internal face accept M3 screws for mounting to a wall, acrylic, or any other flat surface. The Pair of holes on the top and bottom are two run twine through to then be tied onto the headrest poles in your car. The opening in the lower front also allows for the phone to be inserted or removed even if you currently have the charging cable plugged in.

title: Bedini/Cole Window Motor with a Jefimenko electrostatic motor twist
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
The original design for this motor should be credited to John Bedini and Ron Cole. John Bedini is recognized today as an electrical/electronic genius. You can follow this work here: http://www.energyscienceforum.com/forumdisplay.php?f=19 It is not my intention to profit from this work. I only wish to spread the knowledge of this work which has been largely ignored by the general public. This Thing represents a tool to learn about radiant or flyback energy.

The electrostatic component of this motor is my attempt to meld two technologies together. My hopes are to gain additional torque/speed for the motor by ionic induction with little to no additional input energy. You can study the work of Oleg Jefimenko to learn about his atmospheric motors that he developed by searching through the internet.

Update: 10/18/2016 The motor is complete running on the Bedini/Cole Full Sequential Bipolar pulse circuit. At this point the design should remain unchanged. I may add some additional parts at a later date.

Parts List: 8 - 1/4" X 1" non magnetic bolts (stainless steel, nylon, or brass) from Lowe's
6 - 6-32 X 1/2" stainless steel bolts from Lowe's
1 - 1/4" round aluminum stock cut to six 2.25" pieces from Lowes
your choice on the magnet wire and pulse circuit...Study John Bedini's circuits
There is lots of free available information on the internet.
2 - bearings 1/4" X 3/4" X 7/32" from VXBbearings.com
1 - 1/4" X 6" steel shaft from VXBbearings.com
2' of 22 awg stranded wire
aluminum foil and aluminum tape
1 - negative ion generator module that can handle up to a 12V input (can be found on ebay)
4 printed parts. You will need to print two bearing hubs, one for each side.
I printed all of my parts in pla with no problems.
6 - neodymium magnets 1/2" X 2" X 1/4" from www.magnet4less.com
This may be a moderately tough project for most people to build.
Disclaimer: Build at your own risk. This motor/generator can cause injury, death, or damage to property.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=AvyvLNEO9OE

10/29/2016- added a project box/base for this Window Motor. All small holes are for 6-32 stainless steel or brass bolts. The rectangle hole is for a toggle switch. I found this one at Lowe's Home Improvement Warehouse (http://wedo.hillmangroup.com/item/products-12/rocker-switches/50333-a) that fits perfectly. The large round hole can be used for your power cord from a wall-wart or battery pack. There will be more to come;)
